div1.p:
NOTED DOCTORS
AT THE HOPKINS

ATTENDED OPENING OF SURGICAL
LABORATORY.

Appointments and Arrangements Pro-
nounced to Be the Finest in the
Country--Tablet to Memory of Dr.
Lazear, Who Lost His Life in the
Interest of Science--Warm Tribute
Paid to the Hospital--Addresses
Made by Local and Visiting Scien-
tific Men--Those Who Attended.

Learned medical men from far and
near gathered at the Johns Hopkins
Hospital yesterday morning to celebrate
the opening of the magnificent new
surgical laboratory which has just been
completed at the cost of $150,000.

In the afternoon exercises were held
in the clinical lecture-room for the un-
veiling of the bronze tablet to Dr. Jesse
Lazear, and at night Dr. Clifford Albutt,
the eminent physician of London, made
an address to the Johns Hopkins medi-
cal students upon the opening of the
school year.

The new surgical laboratory is de-
clared unequalled by all who have in-
spected it. The surgical amphitheater
is the most up-to-date result of modern
architecture and medical ideas that is
known, and it may well be regarded
with admiration. Built entirely of white
marble, tile, steel and enamel, it is the
embodiment of surgical cleanliness. The
seating arrangement is made of steel
upon a conical foundation of white tile,
which will allow every portion of it to
be easily cleaned, and the facilities for
observing operations are excellent.
Upon either side of the amphitheater
are rooms for special surgical cases,
and all through the four-story building
there are any number of toilet rooms
fitted out with the most perfect and ex-
pensive appointments. There is abund-
ant room for lecturing purposes, and an
improved water-cushion elevator for the
gentle removal of patients from one
floor to another.
A Notable Gathering.

The gathering yesterday was notable,
including physicians from Europe and
many states of this country. The ex-
ercises were opened by Judge Henry D.
Harian, president of the board of trus-
tees of the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
who reviewed the work accomplished by
the university and hospital and impor-
tant incidents of its recent history, es-
pecially the loss of Dr. Osler and the
losses the institution suffered in the
great fire. He also rendered thanks to
Mr. Rockefeller, who came to the aid
of the hospital to offset the reverses
received from the fire.

The exercises were held in the clin-
ical amphitheater, on the first floor of
the new building, and a large number
of extra chairs had to be supplied to
seat the large audience which was pres-
ent.

Dr. William H. Welch, in introducing
Dr. William S. Halsted, surgeon-in-
chief to the hospital, said that the credit
for the new building was largely due to
the latter. Dr. Halsted's address dis-
cussed the points of the new building,
and Dr. Lewis A. Stimpson, professor
of surgery in the Cornell University
Medical School, paid a high tribute to
the prowess of the Hopkins Medical
School, and especially Dr. Halsted, in
surgical science.

Dr. T. Clifford Albutt, regius professor
of medicine in Cambridge University,
spoke in highest admiration for the
progress made by the Johns Hopkins
University in so few years. He said
that he was instrumental in taking Dr.
Osler not to a higher sphere, but to an-
other sphere. He also discussed the re-
lationship which should exist between
the surgical laboratory and the hos-
pital ward.

Prof. Abraham Jacobi, emeritus pro-
fessor of the diseases of children at
Columbia University, New York, could
have uttered no higher compliment to
the Johns Hopkins University than when
he said yesterday that “there is no bet-
ter way to medicine than through the
Johns Hopkins.” Former President Dan-
iel C. Gilman spoke in eulogy of Drs.
Lazear and Walter Reed.
Bronze Tablet Unveiled.

A luncheon was served at noon, and
following this the bronze tablet to Dr.
Lazear in the clinical amphitheater was
unveiled. Dr. Lazear, to whom the tablet
is erected, was assistant resident physi-
cian of the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
when he was appointed in 1900 by Presi-
dent McKinley a member of the com-
mission to investigate yellow fever in
Cuba. The commission succeeded in its
design of preventing the ravages of the
disease, but Dr. Lazear lost his life as a
result of his researches. The addresses
were made by Dr. Osler, Dr. James Car-
roll, of the United States Army; Dr.
William S. Thayer. Drs. Carroll and
Thayer were both associated with Dr.
Lazear upon the commission.

The tablet is about 4 feet by 4 and is
inscribed as follows:

In Memory of
JESSE WILLIAM LAZEAR,
Graduate in Arts at
Johns Hopkins University in 1889
And in Medicine at Columbia University
in 1892;
In 1895-96 assistant resident physician
in the Johns Hopkins Hospital,
Member of the Yellow Fever Commission
in 1900,
With rank of acting assistant surgeon.
He died of yellow fever at
Quemados, Cuba.
September 25, 1900.

With more than the courage and devo-
tion of the soldier he risked and lost his
life to show how a fearful pestilence
is communicated and how its ravages
may be prevented.
Those Who Attended.

ent were:
